Frequency: We propose Bands 3 and 6 continuum observations for spectral and polarisation measurements. Although full polarisation is also available in Band 7, there is only 40% of observing time with suitable weather condition (compared to 100% and 70% for Bands 3 and 6, respectively), which makes the scheduling difficult for the rapid response needed for our project. Therefore, we do not consider that.
Polarisation: Magnetars show highly (80-100%) linear polarisation in radio. We request only full polarisation observations in the first epoch. The three follow-up observations can be made in dual polarisation, since we are mostly interested in the long-term evolution of the flux density rather than the polarisation.
Imaging: Since we do not expect any extended emission, the observations can be carried out with any array configurations.
Sensitivity: We seek to search for magnetar emission down to a sensitivity of 0.1mJy at 3 sigma level, similar to previous studies (e.g., Camilo et al. 2006). This sets our desired sensitivity of 0.033mJy, which require 9min and 17min on source time in Bands 3 and 6, respectively.
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Correlator setup: Default correlator setup is sufficient.
Trigger: This ToO proposal is triggered by new detection of radio emission from a magnetar during an outburst. This ensures that the source is not radio-quiet and the ALMA results could be directly compared to the other radio observations that made the trigger.
Scheduling constraints: After the trigger, we request to make the first observations within reasonable time (~2 weeks) then three additional observations at intervals of two weeks, a month, and two months since the last observation. These give sufficient measurements probe the form of the flux density evolution. We note that both Band 3 and 6 observations are preferably to be taken on the same day, since magnetar emission is known to be highly variable.
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Magnetars are strongly magnetized neutron stars that occasionally exhibit remarkable outbursts. A handful of them have radio pulsations and infrared (IR) emission detected following outbursts. They show many peculiar properties, e.g., flat radio spectra extending to over 100GHz, which are difficult to explain by standard pulsar theories. We propose ALMA observations of magnetars during an outburst to measure the spectral and polarization properties at high radio frequencies. The results will bridge the gap between previous radio and IR detections, offering essential inputs for building a physical model. The new observations will also allow sensitive searches for thermal emission from cold dust surrounding a magnetar, and help determine if the IR emission is generated from the magnetosphere or originates from X-ray heated fallback disks.
